Title: What can developmental psychopathology tell psychoanalysts about the mind?
Abstract: © Ann Casement to the edited collection and the individual authors to their contributions.While the working of the Mozart effect is poorly understood, it is a clear illustration of how a particular specific form of subjective experience can interact at the level of brain function with an apparently independent, important psychological capacity. The brain is the mind’s body and not all the connections that psychological experience makes with subsequent function can be made available through the study of a single domain. Similarly, the impact of psychoanalysis cannot be fully appreciated from clinical material alone. It may be that difficulty in pinpointing the curative factors in psychoanalytic treatment is directly related to the limitations of uniquely clinical basis for inquiry. A cultural shift characterizes the last decades of this century, with both professionals and the lay public switching from an environmental model of psychopathology to a genetic–biological frame of reference that excludes consideration of psychodynamic aspects.
